author: {'steamid': '76561198150588331', 'num_games_owned': 243, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 380, 'last_played': 1704327511}
review:
Not a terrible game, but not an amazing one either. I got it mainly for achievement hunting and to make fun of it on call with a friend.

Every level in the game is basically the same, just changed with different textures and different enemies each time, with a unique boss at the end of each level.

In each level, you have to collect a certain amount of keys around the “crypt” to unlock a gate to the final boss room.

If you are wondering if the keys are hard to spot, they are not. The keys can literally be found in the middle of almost every room you enter.

The enemy AI is hilariously terrible, making the enemies super fun to mess with in certain levels. I will not spoil it, but you can beat this game with very easy exploits.

That is the whole game summed up into a small paragraph. It is not very complex.

TLDR: If you are looking for a cheap and stupid dungeon crawler, a game to farm easy achievements, or a game to mindlessly play while listening to podcasts, this game is for you.

NOTE: If you want to get the game even cheaper than its original price, the game goes on sale for around $0.50 (USD) frequently, so keep your eyes peeled if you want to experience this masterpiece for even cheaper.

review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1700279931}
review:
"Crypt of the Serpent King" is, at face value, a badly made first person brawler with a "dungeon crawler" theme and (very) lightweight RPG elements.  To the point where I am not sure whether this is an asset flip or not.  It has all the hallmarks of an asset flip... mismatched assets combined with what looks like one of several Unity based procgen dungeon crawler templates (there's a bunch of free/cheap dungeon crawler asset packs available for Unity that would be trivial for someone to turn into an asset flip). 

If the developer wasn't known for making other, more genuine (if equally badly made games) I would have made a more rigid judgement on this, but it will have to be up to you, the gamers, to decide here.  All I can say for sure is that this has all the same qualities that you expect from lazy asset flips... mismatched assets, godawfully bad, unpolished gameplay, and as much depth as a tech demo.  There's no real game here for gamers, even if this isn't an asset flip. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

The game assets are far from bleeding edge, with lowish polygon counts and somewhat low resolution textures, making this look like it's at least 10 years old.  It's unclear why the developers weren't able to arrange high quality, high polygon count contemporary assets for the game, and also irrelevant... what matters is that this looks poor in comparison to more professionally produced games as a result of their decisions.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers, or gamers using AZERTY or other international keyboard layouts.  

The game features no proper level design or game/story flow/plot, as they opted to try to use samey repetitive procgen algorithms as a substitute for adding such content to the game, to avoid doing the important job of level/map design.  As a result, the game doesn't actually have any content worth mentioning, just endless, boring, repetitive, soulless algorithmically generated sameyness.  Developers must learn that procedural generation is not an acceptable substitute for content.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

You don't have to take my word about how bad the game is, we can measure the interest in a game by how much people bothered to play it.  "Crypt of the Serpent King" has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game absolutely failed to capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for finishing the first basic "tutorial" level, trivial to achieve, but less than 8 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game.  That's a tiny, tiny proportion of gamers who even bothered with this.  Ouch.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this isn't consistent with the achievement stats, that show less than 8 percent of players bothered playing the game for any reasonable amount of time.  How is it possible for this game to have so many concurrent players who didn't bother engaging with this game?  Trading cards.  People will use card idling software to collect the cards and sell them, but this won't trigger any achievements in-game.

That tells us people only really bought this game for trading cards, and that's a damning indictment of the woeful quality.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with no merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

"Crypt of the Serpent King" is relatively cheap at $2 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.

[b]Note:[/b] Due to the very poor quality of the game, all the comedians came out of the woodwork.  The vast majority of the reviews for this game are joke reviews, such as "this game cured my cancer, saved my marriage, changed my life" etc.  Because most of the reviews are as insincere/mocking the game, and if you removed the fake/joke reviews the game would have a markedly different review score, the positive review score for this game should be disregarded.

review:
"Crypt of the Serpent King", İngiliz geliştirici Wintermaul Games tarafından geliştirilen bir roguelike aksiyon oyunudur. Oyun, zindan keşfi ve sıra tabanlı dövüşlerin yanı sıra birkaç RPG öğesi içerir.

Oyunun amacı, oyuncuların türlü tuzakları, canavarları ve engelleri atlatarak ilerlemek ve sonunda Crypt of the Serpent King'in en derin katmanını keşfetmektir. Oyun, rastgele oluşturulan zindanlar sunar ve her oyun farklı bir deneyim sunar. Oyuncular, farklı düşmanlarla savaşarak, tuzaklardan kaçınarak ve bulmacaları çözerek zindanı keşfederler.

Oyun, basit ama etkili bir sıra tabanlı dövüş sistemi sunar. Oyuncular, mevcut düşmanlarının hamlelerini bekleyerek saldırılarına hazırlanır. Oyun ayrıca, oyuncuların yeteneklerini ve silahlarını yükseltmelerine olanak tanıyan RPG öğeleri sunar. Oyuncular, buldukları hazinelerden ve düşmanlardan düşen öğelerden silahlarını ve ekipmanlarını yükseltebilirler.

"Crypt of the Serpent King", basit grafikleri ve oynanışı ile öne çıkar. Oyun, roguelike oyunları seven oyuncular için mükemmel bir seçenektir. Rastgele oluşturulan zindanları, sıra tabanlı dövüşleri ve RPG öğeleriyle oyunculara yüksek tekrar oynanabilirlik sunar. Oyunun zorluk seviyeleri oyuncuların deneyim seviyelerine göre ayarlanabilir, bu nedenle yeni oyuncular bile oyunu kolayca öğrenebilir. Ancak, oyunun tekrarlanan yapısı bazı oyuncular için sıkıcı olabilir.

review: I don't know why so many people post joke reviews for this game as if it's the second coming of Bad Rats. There is melee and ranged combat with a variety of weapons; the combat is simple but effective. The creature designs and animations are decent. The dungeons probably use stock assets but that's okay, they are well selected and fitted together. The lighting is very good; it creates a foreboding atmosphere and I really like the way the creatures emerge from the shadows. The music is excellent for such a low budget title, and it fits the environment very well. It has both achievements and trading cards. Overall I was pleasantly surprised by this little game, and it held my interest well enough for me to complete it 100% in one sitting. For the fifty cents that I paid for it on sale, I'd call that a win.

review:
With this game, the first things you'll probably notice are:
[olist]
    [*]The visuals aren't super great
    [*]The jumping is janky
    [*]The game seems super difficult at first when you don't know how to play
[/olist]
But if you learn the strategies and how to play in a way that is less difficult for yourself, then this game actually has the potential to be quite fun.

This game is only fun for a short period of time, however. This is because the game boils down to pretty much spamming the same strategies, and going from same-looking hallway and room to same-looking hallway and room, to collect the same keys over and over. Luckily the game is pretty short, and the game should last you long enough to justify the asking price.

The strong suite of these devs would definitely have to be the atmospheric sounds and soundtrack. The battle music is average at best, but the rest of the atmospheric sounds and soundtrack are super great. Generally all being super spooky and enchanting.

Overall, I think this game would be best for achievement hunters and speedrunners. Note that the achievements don't stack for difficulties, so you will need to do 3 separate playthroughs.

Some tips if anyone wants to have an easier time with the game:
[spoiler] Enemies can be avoided entirely. If you don't want to fight them, just run past them. If you keep moving, they won't be able to hit you. The XP they give isn't really important if this is what you're doing. [/spoiler]
[spoiler] Bosses can be beaten by just circling them to the left and attacking them directly after they attempt to attack you. Doing this will ensure you never get hit. For the boss that does 2 swings in a row, just attack after their second swing. [/spoiler]
[spoiler] If skipping enemies, be careful not to let any into the boss room, or things become infinitely harder. You can lose enemies by bringing them to a room where a key is/was, and as the enemies are following you, just jump to the key section, and jump off on the opposite side from where the enemies were following you from. [/spoiler]

review:
-Allgemein:
Ich habe noch nicht viel Zeit drin verbracht aber, für 51 cent im Angebot kann man sich nicht beschweren.
Preis Leistung ist Top bei dem Angebot.
Es ist immer ein kleiner Grusel-Faktor dabei, das das Spiele Erlebnis  Beinfusst. Im großen und ganzen finde ich haben sich 51 cent gelohnt.Kann es für den Preis nur Weiter Empfehlen.

-Noch bissel was zum Spiel:

Man muss pro Level immer den Boss töten. Dafür braucht man Schlüssel, diese findet man im Level.
Um sich zu Heilen kann man Kisten öffnen im Level (diese verbrauchen keine keys) und Essen oder Gold finden.
Mit Essen kann man sich Heilen. Mit dem Gold kann man wen man das Level zu Ende gespielt hat, sich fürs nächste Level bessere Waffen kaufen.
Es gibt 3 Schwirkeits Moduse: Classic, Normal,Experte.
Für Experste muss man den Normalen Modus durchgespielt haben.
Im Classic Modus findet man Viel Essen/Gold und "verdient" auch gut xp.
Im Normalen Modus(wen ich das richtig verstanden habe) ist das recht ausgeglichen.

-Resultat:

Das Spielist kein Brecher bekommt für den Preis aber eine 7/10.
Ein Multiplayer-Modus hätte Potenzial um mit Freunden die Level zu bestreiten.

review:
I had a decent amount of fun with this game. 
I would rate this game positively if only it would be a little bigger and less repetitive. 
This is a very simple game: you have 7 levels, in each level you have 1 type of enemies. So all in all 7 types of enemies + bosses. 
There are treasure chest, containing money for better weapons, food for health or arrows. 
In order to beat each level you have to find all the keys to unlock the boss arena. 
So what's the problem? I just described it. The lack of anything else. The repetition of doing the same thing over and over again. Also, there is only 1 trick in order to beat enemies = circle strafing. That's the only way of not getting hit. All other ways do not work. 
There are only 7 levels on easy, medium and hard for achievement hunters. 
With a little more content it would be a solid game but at current state it's also bugged ( example 1: from time to time the char drops randomly through the floor and can't continue, example 2: all the keys are put on altars, which are always surrounded by lava or spike traps. If you don't jump correctly the char dies and you have to start the level all over again. The problem is, there is only 1 way to jump correctly = to catch corners, all other ways are bugged and the char falls and game over ), so in all honesty I will leave a negative review.

review:
I was challenged to play this game, and I had no idea what I was getting myself into this other then have this thought that this is not going to be a positive experience for me. So I spend a few bucks on this and see what I'm going to be doing. I will say this, I wasn't expecting the game to be like ... this. I'm glad that the video game is short as I beat it in 104 minutes, but the fact that it took that long to beat this game is abysmal. The graphics are so low-poly that I feel like I was playing a game from the PS1 era. It got so difficult at the beginning where I get killed so easily that once I start looking for treasure chests, that's when I figured out what to do, and it does make it super easy to get through. I will say that the hit detect is horrible because I'm never sure if I got close enough to hit the enemies.

Once I figure out how to play, the game gets super repetitive to get through that I'm just wanting to get to the end. It's gotten pretty easy to get through, but once it got to the last level, that's when it got a difficult jump for no reason. Even when I'm at the highest level with the strongest weapons, I still feel like I'm at the same level as the first level from where I started. The bosses are generic to get through and are pretty easy to beat, and the last boss was a pitiful looking final boss where I was trying my damndest to beat this Godforsaken game. Once I beat the game, the end credits are so lazily done that I felt like I accomplished nothing from playing the game. I definitely wasted my money on this short ass game, but I'm glad I got some achievements from the game that'll level up my Steam account. Just watch the playthrough of the game on YouTube, you're better off that way instead of playing the game itself.

author: {'steamid': '76561199086588165', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 288, 'playtime_forever': 1878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1550, 'last_played': 1604161740}
review:
I don't know where to start with this game...
It's brutal, precise and unforgiving...
The roguelike elements are not that much obvious or a focus.
The game saves progression only upon completing a level.
When you die, your experience and gold are not retained.
Speaking of the levels: There are 7 levels to complete on three different difficulties.
Each dificulty is significantly unforgiving, enemies will be really stronger, more resillient... Experience, gold, life and ammo pickups will be way more scarce.
It may seem short but those difficulty will greatly increase the time you'll need to complete the game (Not taking in account card drops).
However, once you get used to to enemies patterns it'll get easier as long as you keep focused.
The goal is simple : you need keys to open boss room and go forward once you've dealt with it. So on and so forth... On your way you can kill enemies, loot gold, arrows an food to restore life.
In terms of graphics, it's really good. There's this tense atmosphere and oldschool vibe...

One thing to remember is that it's not a AAA game by a big studio... Nice work.
Last thing, i noticed rare glitches when playing on PC but nothing alarming (got none on PS4).

I'd strongly recommend it to those not afraid of a bit of challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189265882', 'num_games_owned': 588, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1594697454}
review:
I must say never in all my years as a gamer have I experienced a game quite like this. I originally saw the comedic goblin character and decided I would like to combat the green fella. So I purchased this game and BOY HOWDY did I underestimate what I was getting into. 
This level of the game has your character (who I shall refer to as Grub for the remainder of this review) wandering a labyrinth full of rat-kin. And when you first meet these things. OMG you are not prepared. They swing quickly at you with their pics and on your first few attempts; you will perish, and you will suffer. For you see this game is difficult, as Grub will quickly die to just about anything that tries to touch him so I must say before you read any further that this game is NOT for the faint of heart. 
Now that the babies are gone I can get to some of my gripes with this gift of a game. The level design is pretty limited. Mostly the same traps that surround the keys needed to progress (with the exception of level 2)  and enemies that don't vary much other than appearance. Now not to say these characters don't like frightening as all heck, but it is a shame that most enemies attack with the basic melee moves (the spiders shooting webs or poison or something would be FREAKING SWEET) 
Now onto some golden nuggets of gameplay that I found to be delectable. The stats are pretty cool and allow for some different approaches to each run of the game. Now I found just maxing agility to be the best option (makes you run like Sonic on freaking meth) because I could run circles around enemies while I slapped them with my melee weapon or blasted the bosses with my ranged weapon when I unlocked it. That doesn't mean that there's only one way to play as upon further research I found that I have quite the hot take, so try this game for yourself to see what kind of hero you become. And i'm sure that it will be a magical adventure : ) 

7/10

[i]Crypt of the Serpent King[/i] is a first person dungeon-crawling roguelike game. It's got a suitable level of difficulty, but very little environmental variety and the combat isn't very engaging. Swing, then backpedal. For a game that is built entirely around combat, it probably should have been a little more nuanced. That, plus the jump needs to be a little less piddly, because it's very easy to fudge a jump and fall feet first into lava. There's no way out once you're in, so you die a humiliating death. I did like the enemy variety, and the occasional creepy noise, but in the end, it's nothing amazing. Only buy on sale if you want to try it. I'd like to see an expanded and improved version from the developer, but it's hard to recommend the game in its current state.

review:
Preface:
I accidentally ended up on this game's page while searching for something else. I believe it was a misclick after an error in typing. There were a lot of mistakes involved that allowed me to find this game.

When the video autoplayed on the landing page, I was intrigued by the way the game looks. Mind you, while the game looks very simple, that's what I liked about it. At a price point of $2, you can't ask for much.

At first glance this game looked like a walking simulator with combat sort of... jammed into it. But it reminded me of a simpler time when everyone was using dial-up connections to American Online using Compaq computers and pc games looked pretty much like this but in much less fps. When I was younger, if I saw this, I'd be dying to play it because at the time, I didn't have my own computer. I would only get such chances at school or at a friends house.

The game's appearance took me back, is what I'm trying to say... And while it looked incredibly simple, I had to buy it and play it.

Review:
I have just beaten the game. For $2 of gameplay I enjoyed the game for 2 hours.
The game's graphics look preset, as if the developer didn't actually design any of the assets. However the environments look great for what they are. Everything goes together, nothing really looks out of place with the exception of one enemy I encountered in the sewers.

You play as a dude with a weapon of your choice going through dungeons that look almost randomly generated to find keys surrounded by hazards you have to avoid that unlock a boss room while dodging enemies and attacking them.

-All the enemies have the advantage if you attack them head on. However, all the enemies have the same weakness, sidestepping. It's like they were only programmed to attack where you were when the attack began. So all you have to do to beat the enemy is bait out the attack, sidestep, and return fire. In other words, the A.I is stupid, but for 2 bucks, whatever, I like that. 

-Most of the hazards surrounding the keys boil down to you just jumping over them. One of them is a timed hazard and it doesn't require you to jump at all. Jumping sucks, the animation is too short and it feels wimpy, but it's challenging if the idea is you have to time it exactly right. As far as I can tell, jumping has no practical use in combat.

-You have a good selection of weapons you can purchase with gold you find in chests but they all have relatively short range; Mind you though, with the sidestep strategy, you won't be getting attacked unless you mess up your rhythm or you get attacked by more than one enemy at a time. Later on at a high price, you can purchase ranged arrow weapons.

-There's not much to look at in the environments. Everything repeats so it's nice that the developer included an exact map of where you have been and where you have yet to go. This is much appreciated, otherwise, one could get lost immediately.

-Opening chests and picking up keys is weird because you can only do so by being dead in front of the object and pressing X, which is directly under your WASD keys. It's a little uncomfortable.

-Once you get points invested mostly into Strength and Agility, you can effectively kill most enemies in 2 hits, but you'll have to watch your attack speed, every time you attack quickly, you attack slower, so give a rhythm to your swings and stabs. I really like that there's a bit of strategy involved, even though there's very little of it. Luckily, sidestepping kills everything.

-You will like this game if you want something VERY simple to play with VERY little strategy involved.
-You won't like this game if you don't bother with random games on steam from developers you never heard of that sell their Windows 98 looking games for $2.

I Love it. I'd love to see the concept improved on a larger scale. I knew nothing about it before, I got here by accident, but I like what I found.

I don't think I can fairly grade this game on a normal scale. It implies holding this game to a AAA standard.
That's not what this is. Let's say I give it an american C-. It's not the best, but it's charming.

Absolutely astonishing. Crypt of the Serpent King is a true masterpiece crafted by a mechanical-coding genius. The amount of flexibility there is in the combat system is like none other. With the 100 keys on my keyboard, having the option to bind all 6 controls was a task, but I got used to it after slaying a few rats and goblins. There are plenty of combos to choose from, like: "Kite back-and-forth then swing after the enemy does" "Strafe around the enemy and hit them in the back, cancelling their attack animation" and of course, the very powerful, "Hold the S key and click mouse 1 with the crossbow and/or bow & arrow equipped and win the game". 

I'd recommend perfecting every CS:GO surfing map before even opening the application, because movement in this game is CRITICAL, especially in those closed-corridor boss fights. 

Needless to say, I enjoyed my couple of hours playing this game and plan on earning all 21 achievements the next time I'm mindlessly bored.

review:
To preface all the review, I went into this game completely blind. A friend had originally purchased this game as a joke, but we ended up being pleasantly surprised. While rough around the edges, the game had a certain charm that kept me playing and kept my friend watching.

An unordered list of thoughts:
[list]
[*]Randomly generated dungeon kept it fresh and unpredictable
[*]Dungeon enemy attacks felt fair and had some stradegy, especially the snakes if you were using melee combat.
[*]Audio indication of combat was a nice touch. Ambient tracks were very unsettling in a good way.
[/list]

Some ideas that could make the game better:
[list]
[*]Variety in ways to get some of the keys. The level that had fire obstacles was a nice change.
[*]Traps. Make your player crawl the dungeon with trepidation!
[*]There should be an achievement for playing the game different ways. One example: not killing any of the regular dungeon enemies.
[/list]

And now let me share my first experience... Being that I went in blind, I had no clue what to expect. I found my way through the first level, but level 2 caught me off guard because the enemy's attack was longer range and my hachet was ineffective at taking them down swiftly. I eventually found myself at 6 HP and the game suddenly transformed into a round of Slender where several enemies were pursuing me. As I weaved through the dungeon, I was frantically trying to avoid enemies, collect keys, and find some health. After several hilarious and scary encounters, I fell to the flames of the key. 

All in all, I enjoyed the 1.5 hours I was playing this! For best results, randomly gift this game to a friend and order them to play it. Fun for both will ensue!

author: {'steamid': '76561198122163777', 'num_games_owned': 1846, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1531788790}
review:
I hate to give a game a negative review, especially one so cheap, especially when the developer has clearly put effort into the game, but with no neutral choice available I'm going to have to sway against recommending this title.  The sticking point is that it just doesn't feel like a finished game, the whole thing is more like a demo of what the game could be someday if the developer ever tried to finish it, and what there is to the game currently just isn't fun.

The whole game is too dark, you can't even see monsters until they are right next to you and everything, even the treasure in the chests, is a muted variation of grey, so visually the game is uninspiring.  While the swinging animations of weapons is fluid, you really don't get a feel for power behind the swing, even with higher level weapons.  Also, it is almost impossible to tell how far ahead of you your weapon swings reach, so combat feels lackluster and underwhelming.  The jump (while possibly more realistic than most games) is tiny and is also almost impossible to determin how far forward you move.  Since jumping over lava and traps are auto kills, and you can never improve your jump, and you have to jump multiple times in every level to succeed, this feature makes the game unnecessarily tedious and frustrating.

Probably the worst aspect of this game is the inability to save and load your game.  After you die, you do keep gold and experience earned (on the easiest level), but should you accidentally press back when you go to purchase a new weapon or upgrade your stats instead of start, you are immediately brought to the title menu where the only option is to start a new game and everything you just had is gone.  Plus you can never close down the game and come back to where you were before.

So, even for the price this game is not a deal.  Don't get me wrong this title is pretty cheap, if you enjoy FP hack-n-slash games and you don't mind the absolute bare-bones mechanics, you may want to check it out, but you wont be getting anything more than that.

"You can never improve your jump"

Yes you can. Just use some XP to upgrade your agility, which will make you move faster and jump higher.


"Probably the worst aspect of this game is the inability to save and load your game."

author: {'steamid': '76561198018483984', 'num_games_owned': 1970, 'num_reviews': 132, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1490477410}
review:
I noticed this game when the developers released a demo, which I really appreciate - so if you're wondering if you'll like the gameplay, go check out the first 2 levels for free. Just don't expect the rest of the game to offer anything different. I did enjoy the demo; but made the assumption that the full game had more depth. [b]This is not the case.[/b]

[h1]Dungeon Crawling Gameplay[/h1]

The gameplay is fairly standard for this sort of dungeon crawler, it's a real-time action game, so you walk around and you explore, kill creatures and pick up keys in order to level up and progress to the next level. The movement is simple and well executed, and the animations are smooth and swish.

Unfortunately the levels are extremely repetitive, to the point where most of them feel the same, and the selection of monsters very poor. There is a mini-boss guardian between each level, but they didn't seem to do anything special.  There are also only 7 levels to the entire game (repeatable on 3 difficulty levels), so it's really rather short. There's not a great deal of loot (only gold and health in game, and a very small selection of weapons you can purchase at each level start, no armor or skills or special abilities), and stats don't seem to make a whole lot of difference (and you can max them out by level 5 on casual). There are also no puzzles, and the mapping is standard and predictable, which unfortunately makes this game lack in much of the intellectual variety. 

So, you get where I'm going with this, there's just not enough. It's just shallow. Not enough depth, length, variety or gameplay at all. What is there is done well, and I understand it's a £2 game, but it really feels like the entire game is a Unity demo or concept - and it just needs more more more of everything. Since the levels, monsters and environment lack variety, I was thoroughly bored by the end of casual (approximately 90 minutes). I have no doubt that the harder difficulties are much more challenging - but without any additional monsters, loot or mechanics, I just couldn't find any fun in a further grind.

[h1]Why So Spooky Music Though[/h1]

If there is a mega epic battle around the corner, then the music ramping up in intensity and tone is great. However, the music in this seemed to be slightly confused, as on many occasions it got all excited over absolutely nothing, which really didn't help the tone at all. That wall I just walked into? Yeah, that's not a threat. Sometimes there would be no change in music (there are also no footsteps or noise indicators until you're being stabbed in the back by a goblin), which I suppose added an element of "jump scare horror" to the game when I turned around and realized three orcs were all up in my face.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*] Smooth animations and reasonable graphics.
[*] Low price.
[*] Increasing difficulties for those who enjoy the game and want a challenge.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]  Incredibly simple and shallow gameplay.
[*]  Boring, due to the lack of mechanics and similar environments.
[*]  Weird music issues.
[*]  Very short (90 minutes on the easy difficulty).
[/list]

[h1]TL:DR It's a thumbs down from me; even at £2 - but it's not a terrible game, just short and somewhat limited, with a few creases that need to be ironed out. It might appeal to those who love this genre, especially when it goes on sale or gets bundled. Give the demo a try, as this is basically the entire game but rinse and repeat.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198053422627', 'num_games_owned': 2392, 'num_reviews': 1237, 'playtime_forever': 172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1483212361}
review:
While this game is getting flooded with early negative reviews, I played it my first time expecting to play it maybe 20 to 30 minutes for an first impressions review.. and I ended up playing for about 1 hr and 45 minutes!

Watch my livestream here (my scoring is at 1 Hour and 43 minutes into this video):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zA0y31TsWI0

Using my scoring system I use for all games, which is most heavily based on "value" and asking the question "are you getting a good gaming value for your dollar?".. this game scored an impressive 86% score from me.

The game, while being pretty simple, offers very decent 3D graphics and nice textures and very fluid movement and controls.  Timing is critical, and while I already see some reviews knocking the game for being impossible to jump across lava to get the keys or not being able to hit enemies.. it's all timing and skill based movement to succeed.   Every enemy has a different attack style and speed and method and weapon needed to best defeat them.  If you aren't patient enough (or smart enough) to try different strategies or weapons, then this game might not be for you, but don't knock the game because of your lack of patience or logic.

It's not a AAA game, but I think it's a very nice game for it's asking price, and it offers plenty of replay value as well with randomized dungeon layouts, multiple weapons to buy, and three levels of difficulty, as well as three attributes which can be increased with experience earned.

One note: If you buy this game, PLEASE start on the "easy" difficuluty level which will allow you to save your experience and gold progession and advance through the game without getting too frustrated early on.  

Recommended to people who can appreciate a good old school type RPG game with simplistic controls and a game that will reward you if you go in not expecting a AAA game and if you are logical and patient.  

86% is my score.

review:
-If you want a retro dungeon game, this is it, 10/10.-
Crypt of the Serpent King is a perfect example of a fun dungeon game! All for $2.99.
You go through randomly generated dungeon levels to find all the keys to unlock the door to the dungon boss. The level styles are varied so it doesn't get boring and the levels are huge so your going to be looking at the mini map a lot if you get lost. If you beat the dungeon boss you get to move on to the next level and can upgrade your stats Strength, Agility, and Endurance with the XP you earned from killing enemies, you can also buy new melee and ranged weapons with the gold you found from loot.
-It's a hard game that has 3 difficulty modes.
-The music fits perfectly with the dungeon style of the game.
-The graphics are simple and clean, but modern. It gives the game a nice retro look. The game runs at a solid 60FPS on ultra, and my PC isn't even that good. Really smooth gameplay.
